title: Blue Jays won't sell beer cans in 500 level
text:
Former Cy Young winner Barry Zito announces retirement 
If Blue Jays fans want to show their displeasure in future at the Rogers Centre, they’re going to have find a different way than firing beer cans … At least the one’s in the 500 level area seating will. 
In response to the ALDS Game 5 unrest that saw fans tossing full, half full and even the odd empty beer can onto the field in response to an umpire’s ruling that allowed an opposing run to score, Major League Baseball is clamping down on would-be projectiles from the stadium’s upper level. 
As first reported by MLB on Fox reporter Ken Rosenthal, beer purchased in the 500 level will now be poured into plastic cups. No more cans. #BlueJays adjust beer policy for ALCS: Beer at 500 (highest) level of Rogers Centre will be poured into plastic cups and not sold in cans. — Ken Rosenthal (@Ken_Rosenthal) October 19, 2015 
This response was coming since the 18-minute delay last Wednesday night when all sorts of debris (but mostly beer cans) rained down on the field after plate umpire Dale Scott allowed a Texas baserunner to score from third after Jays catcher Russell Martin’s throw back to his pitcher hit the bat of the Texas hitter and went up the third base line. 
Scott jumped out from behind the plate and seemed to signal time out as Rougned Odor came hustling down the line to the plate, but upon review the run was allowed. 
The morning after MLB suggested measures would be taken to prevent a reoccurrence. 
“The highly unfortunate reactions of a group of fans at Rogers Centre in Wednesday's game represented a major source of concern,” MLB said in a statement Thursday. “We appreciate the response of the local authorities and the Blue Jays stadium operations staff in identifying, ejecting and - in some cases - arresting the offenders. 
“We will discuss comprehensive security plans for upcoming postseason games in Toronto and reiterate the importance of fans observing the appropriate code of conduct,” MLB said. “Setting yesterday's situation aside, the enthusiasm from Toronto fans in recent months has been extraordinary. We will do everything we can to foster a safe and fan-friendly atmosphere at Rogers Centre and to ensure that a situation like Wednesday's will not be repeated.”
